element_texts.text: Completed

in pencil in top margin  Sowerby, Benn
letterhead  West 834  Elmwood,  St. Mary,  Jersey, C.I.
6th Aug.
Dear Conroy,

   I hope you will not be returning to the States at the end of August.  Unfortunately my plans have had to be changed, and I cannot now get to England before about September 18th.  My wife and I are then collecting a motor caravan and expect to leave for the continent soon afterwards.  At present we are back here for about five weeks.  Will there be any chance of seeing you in September?  Your letter has been following me about, with delays due to the postal strike, and has only just reached me.
Completed

The book has arrived also.  Many thanks!  I am greatly enjoying it.  I admire the objectivity of the narrative and the economy of many of the descriptions.  It certainly strikes me as in the tradition of Defoe, a writer I much respect.
  It is very kind of you to interest yourself so on behalf of "Fright in the Forest."  I offerred [sic] it to innumerable publishers before it was finally accepted:  but my later efforts have met with even less success.  Several publishers have expressed their appreciation but regretted that probable sales would not justify publication.  The most enterprising, John Calder, very nearly accepted one, but finally turned it down after retaining the MS for twelve months.
   I do hope we can arrange a meeting somewhere, some time, while you are still over on this side.

All best wishes.
Benn Sowerby
Completed

P.O. Box #15057
Phila. PA. 19130
8 July 1976
Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Avenue
Moberly, Missouri, 65270
Dear Mr. Conroy.

    We are presently investigating the development of black writers from 1925-1945.  Our interest was greatly stimulated by a current project we're doing on Prof. Sterling A. Brown.  It will be completed this summer.  Gerre Mangione suggested you as being quite knowledgeable about the black writers involved in the WPA Writer's Project.   We would appreciate your reflective comments on the following black writers:
   Gwendolyn Brooks, Katherine Dunham, Margaret Walker, Horace Cayton, Sterling Brown, Ross D. Brown, Harry Denn, Margaret Burroughs, Langston Hughes, Anna Bontemps, Roscoe Dunjee, Richard Wright, Frank Yerby, Fenton Johnson, Paul Robeson and any others which may be omitted.

Keep in mind the following questions when commenting on these individuals:
A.  When and how did you first meet them?
B.  Did you have any experience with them as an editor, friend, colleague, political comrade, etc.?
C.  Did your publications give critical attention or space for including their works?
D.  What is your evaluation of their writings?
E.  Cite some memorable experience with the individual or folk tale regarding said individual.
Generally speaking what was the attitude of white editors and authors toward their "black" peers.  Or were they perceived in that way?  The evidence suggest [sic] that general American Anthologies excluded the works by blacks.  do you feel this is/was due to a racial bias on the part of the editor?

    Thanks for your consideration given this inquiry.  If you want to do it in installments begin with Sterling Brown, Ross O. Brown, Gwendolyn Brooks & Katherine Dunham.
    We shall await your earliest possible reply.

What black writers were there in Moberly, Joplin, St. Louis & other parts of Missouri.
Sincerely,
James G. Spady,  Editorial  AMuM
Completed

9-17-79
P. O. Box # 15057
Phila. Pa.  19130
Mr. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Avenue
Moberly, Missouri,  65270
Dear Mr. Conroy,

       Again, I'm returning to your memories.  First, how are you doing?  or as the old man said, "How is life serving you?"  Fine, I hope.
      Have those memoirs been published yet?  I recall a few years back you began publishing excerpts from your autobiography in some midwestern literary journal.
      Presently, I'm examining the works of Katherine Dunham as an anthropologist.  did you ever meet or know her or can one assume that your knowledge of her is through legend and folktales?  Can you tell me who followed Dunham as Group Leader of cult studies in the Chicago WPA Project?   Who else was in that group?  How long did you study the cults?  Did it include the Moorish-Americans  (led by the Noble Drew Ali) and the Nation of Islam (commonly called, "Black Muslims" - led by Honorable Elijah Muhammed?  In addition to the materials include in underlined:  They Seek A City,  did you or Arna or other members of the project publish an article or articles on the cults in Chicago?
     I saw mention of a Japanese graduate student and Katherine Dunham publishing an article during the 1930's or 40's.   A check of the scientific literature does not reveal such a publication.   Did you or Arna come across it in your research for the book?  Did you ever see a copy of Dunham's paper on "The Occurance of Cults Among "Deprived' Peoples." ? 
    Finally what happened the manuscripts, ?memorsh....? photographs and tapes done on the cults?   Where are they deposited?   Do you know of any in private collections?
    Would appreciate your earliest possible response.  Enclosed is a recent article I did on Paul Robeson.

Sincerely,  James G. Spady
Completed

in pencil in top margin Spector, Burt
3-6-80
letterhead  LONGVIEW Community College  500 Longview Rd./Lee's Summit, Mo.  64063/(816) 763-7777
Dear Jack,

  Mary Ellen and I wanted to thank you again for your kindness on our recent visit to the Athens of the Midwest!!
  We enjoyed meeting you and visiting with you.
   By the way, we both saw the review of your reader in the underlined:  New Republic.  Very impressive.
  Take care of yourself, Doctor.  We're looking forward to seeing you when you come to Kansas City.  Best regards to your wife.

Peace,
Burt Spector
Completed

"Bowshots"
41 Havestine Hill
Caterham  Surrey
14/10/45
Dear Mr Conroy

    I have received my copy of "They Seek a City" & have to thank you for your kindness in attaching your autograph.
    I have much enjoyed reading it & I can assure you that it will take its place in my collection of
Completed

special editions.

    I didn't know what Dan Rischer has been telling you about me, all I did for him was to try & stop him spending his money!
    Thank you once again.

Yours sincerely
C. W. Speller
Completed

36, St. Peter's Road,
Wolvercote,  Oxford

Delighted to receive the (much) inscribed essay on Dreiser, which I enjoyed -- never, I must confess, having heard of him until Don originally mentioned this article, and I had to look him up!  I shall have to remedy this.
David

postmark  OXFORD  196[torn away]]
Mr & Mrs. Jack Conroy,
7027, S. Jeffery BoulevaRd,
CHICAGO, ILLINOIS.  U.S.A.
Greetings to you both from Oxford!  You saw practically the only rain we've had in two months and it  continues hot and dry -- ideal for the visitors and those on holiday....but not so good for the underlined:  workers.  I hope you've given Don a full report?  
David
Completed

in pencil in top margin David
card
Christmas greetings!
I was glad to have your card and the news of They Seek A City - which I await with interest.  And very glad to see you in the States, even under overwhelming ? hospitality!

  It's been very hard to get down to work again after that very exciting holiday and I hope it won't be long before I return to your country.
  But perhaps you'll be visiting England before then?

All good wishes from
David
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Spencer, Onah
Dear Jack:

     Sent you the wrong "Four seasons on canal"  This was the one that needs a little Social and literary build-up.
     As I'm trying to get it in the sooner the better let Max look it over & tell him I can turn out lots of stuff for Mens Magazines with offices in Chicago.
     Am supposed to be on line for Carson Show - Down Bert Jazz Folklore Jokes etc.   Hope to also do you some good.
     Just run over a couple and forget the others.

Hurriedly, But
Sincerely
Onah
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Onah?   [ 16 Jan 1963  O. Spencer]
Dear Jack:

     How are you & family?  Well, I do hope.  Looks like it will be March before I am on my feet & perculating again.  Have a variety of notes & clippings on subjects saved to insert in letters to you, but they are at my house & looks like a couple weeks yet before I leave my sister's place where I am at present.  Result, I'm short on underlined:  brilliant subjects to discuss.
    Read Nelson's "Walk on the Wild Side," & liked it a lot.  Missed the movie which I wanted to see for comparison as I imagine it was hoked beyond recognition.  Yet I thought they did a pretty good, in fact excellent job on "Man With Golden Arm"   My favorite of all I've read by Nelson is still "The Face on the Barroom Floor."  Fact is, in my opinion, it is one of the greatest short stories of all time.
   As I mentioned in last letter been too busy with family affairs going to work & stopping too often at taverns to catch up with reading.  However, at no time did I neglect making copious notes on my book & other shorter pieces.  Result, I have besides the book a number of 

(over)
Completed

stories & articles, likely very commercial, as all are the fruit of some forty years research, compiling & burned  up candles.  All they need is a little more organization & polishing.  Reason none are finished is, without an agent I saw no underlined: definite markets, therefore I'd drop one & start another.  I believe all of them to be as unique as "Stackalee" & in some cases better written.

  I've blabbed so much here about myself, I forgot to ask you if you have had time to put out anything lately.  If so please let me know as I'm woefully behind in my reading.
  How is Jackie, is he still in the Northwest?  Please excuse pencil, intended to copy this over with pen but a lot like the old fellow on horse back who thought he saw a ghost, jumped off the horse & ran so fast & low to the ground that his hip pockets were full of underlined:  dry sand despite the fact he had splashed all the water out of a half dozen creeks he had crossed.  When asked why he didn't stay on his horse replied:
   When I get scared enuff to do some real runnin' I aint got no time to be bothered with no hoss.
   Point is, if I stop to be bothered with a pen I dont get much down on paper.  Bottom of page.  More next time.  Good luck ol pal   Onah.
Completed

Dear Jack:

    While rushing to post office thought of those clippings I intended to send you long ago - that is before they flaked beyond incomprehensbility [sic]  (excuse the big word just wanted to smarten you up - ha!    Onah
Completed

Jack
Your story Pipe Line is mentioned in Uzzels Narrative Technique American Mercury  Sept 1932
Completed

greeting card  Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year
Pat & Marv Spira
Dear Gladys & Jack - 

   Our heartiest congratulations on your degree.  I have always been in awe of people who are accorded an honor like that so I'm very impressed!  I'm thinking of getting my Masters in Arts Administration next year but a Doctor of Letters & Science - WOW!
    Have you ever written a children's play?  Somehow I keep thinking that
Completed

greeting card
IMAGE Santa Claus showing bag full of gifts to small dog.  Decorative hearts, bell, star and wreaths border the picture.   From an original by Ursula Arndt.  Exclusive Representative H. George Caspari, Inc.

either you & Arno Bontemps wrote a play or someone adapted your story to a play.  If so can you please send me the script immediately -
Best regards to you both,
Pat
Completed

Feb 10, 1951
Dear Jack -

    This is a dull town.  A very dull town.  So - upon arriving in Milwaukee I decided that I would go in and meet Harry Schwartz of whom you and Nelson had spoken so fondly.  I duly announced this intention to you and received your communication.  Armed with this I marched in, spoke to him for a few minutes and from that meeting I have decided that I adore Dale Kramer.
   When is your book coming out?  When it does I expect you to go right to Stuart's and charge two of them to me and autograph them.  One for my David and one for Pat, Mary, & Nancy Silk.  Stuart can send them on to me.  I solemnly
Completed

pledge to buy only your book for birthday presents from now on.  O.K.?

   My regards to all the Conroys -

Patsy

If you have any story or photo ideas - anything - please write or call collect, maybe I'll get to drop in when I'm down your way.    D.S.

in pencil in top margin  Steiner, Nina
Hermann, Mo.  65041
303 West 8th St.
June 30, 1978
Jack Conroy
Moberly, Missouri
Dear Sir:
My Mother and I read an article about you in Sunday June  25 St Louis Post Dispatch.    She found it especially interesting for she said she is sure she went to school with you.  We are wondering if you are the same Jack Conroy.  My Mother's maiden name was Margarite Halsey - she was born in Moberly and went to school there - I believe she lived on Randolph Street, she had a younger sister, Velma Opal Halsey.  My Mother later married Gilbert Broeber and they moved from Moberly but she still talks so much of her home town.  She was born Sept. 19, 1901 - my parents have a  infant son buried in one of Moberly's cemeterys. sic
If you are the same person I would appreciate it if you would write her a note - her health
Completed

isn't too good and she isn't able to get out much - it would certainly brightened [sic] her day.

    I have never read any of your books but fully intend to do so.  Thank you for your time.

Sincerely,
Mina Steiner
PS.
My Mothers address is:
Mrs. Margaret Groeler
120 West Eighth St.
Hermann, Mo.  65041
Completed

Santo Domingo
Rep. of Dominicana
October 26, 1975
Dear Jack,

     Forgive my delay in responding to your good letter and enclosure of fine statement and poetry, but I have been much occupied in the weighing of and the final decision of changing S&S from periodical to anthology.  It was not an easy task.
    Ashley did a fine job on Jack Conroy, but then he had good material to work with!  If acceptable to you, several of your poems will appear in the 1976 Anthology & the remainder (along with your "biog-sketch", statement, and other poems) in the 1977 Anthology.   Perhaps you could send others (poems) for the '77 edition?
     Your "bio-sketch" will appear as is.  If it goes against one's grain, too bad.  I long ago cease to allow others to dictate to me.  One should "write" his own life; if there is a misspelled word or wrong tense, so be it - at least they will be his own mistakes or experiences, whichever way he interprets it, right?
     Your life & work will add much to those of our readers ...already, they have to mine!  Warm Regards, Jean
Completed

Lucille R Stern

postcard  File:Barefoot boy and girl holding hands and walking
postmark  AUSTIN, TX  PM  20 MAR 1976
Apt. 466, 1201 So. Congress
Austin, Texas, 78704
Mr & Mrs Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly
Missouri
65270
Completed

3/19/76.  Thanx for Vibrations, Writers in Revolt, etc. You can be sure that as always we will do all we can to keep your things read.  We've been thru 4 of the kind of problems (such a small word) you have with your daughter.  One, we had to take turns at the bedside, never leaving one of our best friends & a good poetess alone the last few months.  Turned me into an alcoholic & Harvey to a despondent.  our 7 pictures in '74 show you look the same & haven't lost any hair.  How do you do it?  UT has a fabulous library with tons of material from 20th C. Writers, some still alive, but its going to take longer than we thot, mainly because Snow's M.S. is in the usual illegible Br. handwriting.  Glad you like Macaulay who seems to not be much read now.  We saw her in London in her last years & they don't make women like her anymore, even if they don't write.  You know she was bombed out & the apt we saw her in was in a place where friends had chipped in things to make it a home.  all of which she took in stride, riding a bicycle during blitz, scaring riders to death driving her car  Hope collected works are no longer stalled  Keep us posted  Seems SanFriciso [sic] gets news better than we.  All we know old stuff to T.J.P.  Write!  Love, H & Lucile
Completed

New address:  2709 ½ Strong's Drive   Venice, Calif.
May Day, 1963
Dear Jack -

     I feel good all over, in spite of being sick as an old hound dog with a virus.  I just finished underlined:  The Disinherited, which - can you believe it? -- I had never read before.  Just as the original edition heralded the renaissance of the thirties, so I think the current edition is going to spark another and better revival of left writing.
    Forgive this scrawl as I'm in bed with a fever, but I  had to tell you right away.  A great rough-hewn book, one that old Walt Whitman would have cheered for and been proud of - as you should be proud all over again.  For the book doesn't "date" at all.  It's as much of our time as is the fracas going on around Harlan County, Kentucky.  And the language is living and vibrant.  A thousand thanks for your rare gift, friend.
   I didn't know you knew Arthur Ficke.  I was in Mexico with him (& our wives) for about 6 months in 1934.  I was writing a play for the underlined:  Theatre Union that never got produced.  It's curious that you and I have never tangled; we had so many things and people in common.  We'll make it yet!
Completed

Warm good wishes for a big sale of this edition -- and, in general, good writing!

Phil S.
Did Mike Hecht ever ask you about reviewing my vols. 3 & 4 for the Times?
Completed

Dear Jack and Gladys,

   It seemed so good to see you at your autograph party.  crossed out:  Not only After we talked and you autographed my book, I was telling the friend I came with about it.  Not until then did I remember the elaborate story told in "After the Ball Was Over."  Gradually it all came back to me, so we must sing it again soon.  I enjoyed your speech and have enjoyed your Introduction to your book.  It seems like
Completed

hearing you talk.

    I'm sending on the tracts you sent me to Dave Abbott, formerly Managing Editor of the College Dept. at Scott Forsman.  He'll get a kick out of them I think.  He was a good friend of your co-author, Curt Johnson.
   My only regret was that I failed to get an autographed copy of your book for Charles Sweetland.  I just plain didn't think of it until Harold Meigs mentioned that he had
Completed

planned to do that.   Maybe I'll get him one sometime and send an extra end-paper to you to autograph.

    You look so much the same as you used to that I would hardly believe the newspaper's statement of your age.   I'm 66 now, retired last year, and I thought you were my age.

Regards to you both,
Jerry Stewart
in pencil at bottom of page   [1975?]
Completed

Sat 3 sep  underlined:  In the Year of the Bomb - X
Hi, Jack
The person I'm having my visit with, one Harry Sutonen, just came in with a book by Murry Kempton:  Part of Our Time in which a quotation of yours helps to decorate the beginning of chapter 4.  And then I met a Larry Lipton (20 Park Ave, Venice, Calif.) who has taken a vow of voluntary poverty and a third spouse and who remembers you from the old days.  He gave me an autografed [sic] copy of his latest book of verse:  Rainbow at Midnite.

   ¶ Do you remember an S. P. Rudin?  He's out this way too... 
   ¶ I expect to leave Mon. or Tue. and return to Chicago via Seattle.
   ¶ I lost my address book so give my regards to Statman et al.

in pencil in right margin  Stewart. Joffre  [1955]
Completed

seal with shield;  SIGIL - UNIVERSITATIS  - MISSOURIEN  - MDCCCXXXIX -

5315 HOLMES  KANSAS CITY, MISSOURI 64110    TELEPHONE  (816) 276-1305

Friday
Dear Jack,

    Thanks much for helping with our Wright program.  We want to have you back in a principal rather than a supportive role.  And one day I want to get to Moberly for a more leisurely perusal of your collection and more good talk.

Sincerely,    Bob
Completed

letterhead  Ross-Loos Medical Group  947 West 8th Street   Los Angeles 14, California
October 1, 1945
Dear Jack:

      Your good letter reached me a few days ago - together with the enclosures of another of the publication of your new book, and the review by Dorothy Caufield.  I sent the review on to W. G. Clugston in Topeka who is much interested in your work - and he will see to it that it gets about among our Topeka friends.  You may remember Clugston - he published a book on Kansas fathers a few years ago called underlined:  Rascals In Democracy.
   It is good to hear from you and to know that prospects are looking bright for underlined:  They Seek a City.    I am getting a copy and looking forward to enjoying it a lot.
   I've been swamped in work all summer; in fact ever since landing in this place.   Had a two weeks vacation the last of August and spent the time divided between San Francisco and Carmel.  We saw Alan Swallow in S.F. whom I think you know.  He is a sergt. in the Medical Corps at
Completed

Letterman General Hospital - and hopes to be discharged this fall some time.  I am hoping he will get on with the English Dept at U.C.L.A. - He used to be ? Editor, - and I think still is - of the New Mexico Quarterly Review - and taugh [sic] in the English Dept there - before the draft caught up with him.

   I see Peterson now and then.  He is still working in the Accounting office of Lockheed Aircraft Cooperation.  We ? back and forth.   I think he will get back to writing again but has been crowded for time - with a family of two small youngsters - and all that -  We have become very good friends - but in this wide city one doesn't get to see their friends as often as we would like --
    I am visiting the book stores as I get to them and suggesting they stock underlined:  They Seek a City.  and will do all the boosting I can for it.  so far I haven't seen it reviewed in any of the L.A. papers - and perhaps I can stimulate something in that line -  In the rush of work I haven't had a chance to
Completed

letterhead  Ross-Loos Medical Group   947 West 8th Street   Los Angeles  14, California
do any writing but hope when the doctors get back from the Service I'll be able to take time off to et something done that I've been thinking about --

   I'll be seeing Peterson some time soon and will pass on the good word from you.
   Write me again Jack and let me know how things go.

With warm regards -  As Ever    Bob Stewart
Completed

letterhead Robert B. Stewart, M.D.   947 West Eighth Street   Los Angeles, California
December 29, 1946
Dear Jack -

      Your good letter of the 6th was heartily welcomed - I am glad to know that underlined:  Slappy Hooper is out and since hearing from you I've been watching the book pages of the local commercial press - without finding notice of it.   But in last Saturday's underlined:  Peoples World is a notice of the book - which I am enclosing herewith -
   I ordered a copy at the local "Progressive Book Shop" and called their attention to it, so I think they intend to stock it - underlined:  The Lincoln Book store in Hollywood also specializes in leftwing literature - and we will get up there soon and suggest it be made available.
   So far, I am sorry to say, I haven't gotten down to writing that article on negros in Medicine - It has been very difficult to get Material and facts. and I've been crowded for time - We have put in a plan of graduate teaching in the hospital where I work - and I have had to devote a lot of time to teaching and
Completed

demonstrating surgical operations  - and all that in addition to a big load of clerical work - which hasn't given me time for writing as I should like to do -   I have been doing a few book reviews for the underlined:  World In Books - a Boston publication which started up about a year ago.  Most of my reviews have been of scientific books - but when I receive underlined:  Slappy Hooper I intend to sent them a review of it.

    Thanks for the suggestion about underlined:  Negro Digest - an excellent idea. 
     I never hear from Elrick Davis = the last I knew of him he had written a book about underlined:  Alcoholics Anonymous - ghost writing for someone - and Angelus Burch - who used to be an editorial writer on the Cleveland Press - now with the Chicago News - told me that Davis was quite sold on the idea -  He was such a devoted drinker that it is hard to imagine --
   Did you know that Alan Swallow has gone into the publishing game - rather seriously?  He is teaching in the English Dept. of Denver University - doing some publishing of small editions on his own and has an agreement with William Morrows for more pretentious publications - 
   The best of good fortune for the New Year - and write me again -

As ever
Bob Stewart
Completed

letterhead  ROBERT B. STEWART, M.D.  947 WEST EIGHTH STREET   LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA
March 16, 1047
Dear Jack:

     Thanks for your good letter of February 26th and the enclosed clipping - I'm still interested int the Negro doctor problem but will gather more data before getting the article up in shape.  
    As to underlined:  Slappy Hooper The Progressive Book shop here was so long getting me a copy that I began to think it would never come - but finally this last week it came along and I'm glad to say that the shop had ordered a stack of them - so they are on sale.  The book is nicely gotten up and the illustrations are really excellent.  I am going to send a review of the book to underlined:  World In Books which publication is quite widely circulated.
   I hope Crawford and Clugston will give you something - Especially Crawford should be able to direct you to some good Kansas humor -
Completed

but the man most likely to be of help to you is Kirk Mechem, secretary of the Kansas State Historical Society.  He is a good chap and a good writer and very good friend of mine, if you write Mechem tell him that I suggested that you write him.  He may be able to lay his hand on some good stuff in his collections.  I have another thought.  Do you remember old Ed Howe of the underlined:  Atcheson Globe - who wrote underlined:  The Story of A Country Town many years ago?  He was known as the Philosopher of Potato Hill.  While Howe wasn't a humorist he did write some good first rate humor in his way.  H. L. Mencken once told me that Edgar Lee Masters told him that he would not have writtenunderlined:  Spoon River if he hadn't first read underlined:  The Story of a Country Town.
Completed

letterhead  ROBERT B. STEWART, M.D.  947 WEST EIGHTH STREET   LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA

   Have you seen Fred Holly's Biography of George Ade?  I just received a copy of it from the publishers, (Bobbs Merrill).  but haven't had time to read it.  Kelly is an old High School friend of mine - now lives in Peninsula Ohio.  A good Irishman - and good company - if you ever have a chance to visit with him.
   I haven't yet seen underlined:  Neon Wilderness but will look it up.  Sounds good.
   Things are looking a little dark for the left-Wing these days.  The worst thing in the immediate future is the Red Hunt - and the Next Thing is the Dulles, Vandenberg, Truman adventure - to take over the British Empire.  There is a tremendous protest against Truman's speech to Congress and public opinion may be able to prevent acceptance of his proposals.
   It has just occurred to me - through a suggestion
Completed

from my wife - that you should see Tom McNeal's Fables.  They deal with early Kansas and McNeal was an outstanding humerist. [sic]  Until his death about 1942 he was with the Capper Publications - Topeka -

    If time hasn't run too short I should like to suggest that you write to Tom McNeal's daughter - Miss Louise McNeal, Librarian, Kansas State Library, Topeka and she can furnish you with her father's work.  I think you might find some important humor in Tom McNeals writing.
    I wish that this thought about McNeal had not come to me so late - but you may be able to stretch that Deadline a little --
    Let me know how things go.

As ever
Bob
Completed

letterhead  ROBERT B. STEWART, M.D.  947 WEST EIGHTH STREET   LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA
underlined:  October 25,  1947
Dear Jack =

    Thanks for your letter and the Announcement of publication of your underlined:  Midland Humor.
    Congratulations on getting out this collection.
    I'm glad you included Tom McNeal - and to be included Charley Edson will appreciate it -  If raw alcohol hasn't killed him yet - he is still around Topeka.
    I am writing W. G Clugston to ask him to boost the book in the Topeka area.  I'll do all I can out here --
    When are you coming out this way?

As ever
Bob
Completed

letterhead  ROBERT B. STEWART, M.D.  947 WEST EIGHTH STREET   LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA
underlined:  September 21, 1949
Dear Jack =

      Thanks for your postcard which I found in my mail on returning from vacation the first of this week -   Glad to know you were at the famous place and hope you stayed long enough to do what you wanted -
      I just went to Carmel, Calif- where we have had vacations for many years.  Used to see Lincoln Steffens there and had many good talks with him -  In his last year or two he was propped up in bed with a typewriter in front of him =
     I like Carmel, with its mist hanging over the Jeffers hills.  I didn't see him this trip but I think he was at home - as the dim light burned in his house as usual.  I don't like
Completed

his philosophy - but the guy underlined:  can write and I like to read him -

    I started reading Sandburg's novel, [[underlined:  Rememberance [sic] Rock]] while away and I am only about half through it now.  I don't think Carl would have attempted a novel unless he thought he had something to say in this particular art form.  So far I am quite impressed with the story and the writing.  It seems to me he handles his women very well -
    I'm still working in this Ross-Loos Medical Group and doing a lot of surgery.  It is a pre-pay place - (on the insurance bases) and for me is a good way to practice medicine.
    It is possible I may be in Chicago in October to attend the meeting of the American College of Surgeons   If I get there will look you up -

All good wishes --
As ever -
Bob
Completed

letterhead  ROBERT B. STEWART, M.D.  947 WEST EIGHTH STREET   LOS ANGELES 14, CALIFORNIA
December 12, 1949
Dear Jack =

     I was glad to find your good letter in my mail on returning from a weeks medical meeting at Santa Barbara -
    No, I wasn't able to get away for the Chicago meeting in October.  I surely would have looked you up and should have written you I wouldn't be there.
    I have seen the reviews on Algrens book but havent yet read it.  Masses & Mainstream hop on him for not being more prolabor - answer - a man writing about life sees life through trained eyes and somewhat disciplined emotions.  These times a writer would have to hunt around to find a prolabor character even among the working
Completed

class =

   Incidentaly [sic] don't you think organized labor is less "politically advanced" now than during the Roosevelt days --
   I imagine you had an interesting session with Algren and Sandburg.  I don't know Algren personally but I do know old Carl - and he is lively company when in the right mood.
   As to Elreck B - I had a note written on a Christmas Card last year.  I wrote him but didn't ? any more correspondence from him.  His home address is 126 East 34th St. N.Y. City zone 16.  if you would like to try him there.
    You should underline:  somehow make a time to write that novel.  It is important.
    Thanks for the folder concerning the Poe book -
    I hope you have a fine Christmas  Wish you were going to spend it out here -

All best wishes -
as ever
Bob
Completed

Dear Jack =  I was glad to get your card - and to know the novel is as far as a publisher =  I came up here to see my brother - who was critically ill at Letterman Hospital.  He died Tuesday morning = I am in no shape to write a letter now but will do so from Carmel where I will be for the next 3 weeks -  as ever - Bob
Jack Conroy
6012 So. Green St
Chicago - 21  Ill

letterhead  ROBERT B. STEWART, M.D.  947 WEST EIGHTH STREET   LOS ANGELES 14, CALIFORNIA
October 20, 1950
Dear Jack =

     Thanks for sending me the copy of Chicago Public Library Book Bulletin.  I read with much interest the little biographical sketch - and it brought back memories of underlined:  The Anvil and underlined:  The New Anvil which you worked so hard to keep going =  The fine selections of material you printed.  You were an effective Crusader and I imagine a big help to many younger writers.  And I recall the enthusiasm with which I read underlined :  The Disinherited and reviewed it for the underlined:  Topeka Daily Capital.
    A lot has happened since those days and I guess we both have seen a lot and learned a good deal -- and while still Crusaders at heart it is quite surprising to me to see the fascist drift of our country - the failure of all
Completed

progressive movements to stem the tide of reaction =  Of course we have had good reason to know this is a phase through which our Country must pass, in the historic process = nevertheless it is a very distasteful performance.

    The American Legion national meeting here reached the heights of vulgarity.  
    But we must be optomists [sic] in "the long view" -  We must have the vision and the heart for that x
     Thanks again for sending me the Bulletin - and let me know now and then how things go with  you.

As ever
Bob
Completed

1-14-54
Dear Jack =

     Thanks for your Christmas greeting card and the enclosed note.  I hope this will be a underlined:  big year for you and good luck with the two books.
     I'm only telling a few friends at the present that as of Feb. 1 I am leaving this Clinic - after eleven years - and great surgery - I've been at it long enough -  Maybe I'll get to finish a medical novel started about twenty or so years ago.
    Change my address to Apt 4 -  449 South Alexandria    Los Angeles 5 -

As ever
Bob Stewart
Completed

in pencil in top margin  1954
greeting card  Merry Christmas And Best Wishes For A Happy New Year
Dear Jack= Sorry to learn that you have had a bad  year.  I'm having trouble right now with Anemia which the Docks havent been able to explain.  Its disabled me to where I can't get around much and I don't know the answer to it at present.

    I hope the New Year brings you some measure of good fortune to make up for this last year.
    Its good they knocked McCarthy's ears down  Maybe its a good indication that our foreign policy is so weak and so many of the war-wanters getting space in the news that it makes me sick at the outlook.
    So good luck to you for the coming year and lets hope for a better outlook -

As ever   Bob Stewart
Completed

letterhead  ROBERT B. STEWART, M.D.  947 WEST EIGHTH STREET   LOS ANGELES 14, CALIFORNIA
in pencil in top margin  Stewart, Bob
12-18-58
Dear Jack=

     Thinking of you and not having a formal Christmas Card at hand - I'll send my yearly greeting anyway - knowing you will forgive the lack the usual symbols adorning messages at this time of year.
    So - my good wishes and hopes that things are going well with you.
    I had a short visit with Elrick B no period Davis a few months ago - when he was in Los Angeles in passing through.  Later he wrote me that he found a spot on underlined:  The Sun.  I have wondered if you have seen him.

With warm regards -
As ever
Bob Stewart
Completed

Dear Jack =

    Wishing you the best of everything for the Christmas season and New Year -
     The Progressive Book Shop has had a good sale on underlined:  They Seek a City and inquiring about among the other book stores indicates that Los Angeles people have been buying the book -  I've read it carefully and enjoyed it immensely-   It is an excellent piece of work and I want to congratulate you and your associate on it --
     I am trying to collect some material on negro physicians in the USA and the opportunities offered for Negro men and women to obtain
Completed

medical education in "grade A" Medical schools - also what chance negros have for graduate study leading into the Specialties - 

   You perhaps know we have a dozen or more specialty Boards which grant certificates in the various specialties - It takes three years graduate preperations [sic] to qualify for these Board Certificates - 
   I've recently started looking for material and hope to be able to write a magazine article on the subject.  If you should know of any data on this subject I would appreciate your telling me how to get it.

As ever
Bob Stewart
Completed

Wolfpen Creek, BATH, Kentucky       3 Nov 50

     Your book, underlined:  Midland Humor, is very fine.  I found it happy reading.  On arriving at page  441 I wanted more... (Why not edit a volume of Kin Hubbard's wit and wisdom?)  Thank you for sending the book to me -
      I'll write a letter soon.
      When you come south, come to see me.  Bring your wife and younguns.

Sincerely,
James Still

in pencil in top margin  Stout, Jean  [no date]
letterhead  Mrs. william a. stout . crossed out:  435 n. hugh street - barrington, illinois   212 California  Mill Valley, Calif.
Dear Jack -

      Your Christmas notes are always so welcome and I save each year's tracts and enjoy them over and over.  We do appreciate the "vote of confidence" you gave Mill Valley.  We love it out here, and I love Sausalito too.  My aunt and uncle are artists, you know, and live in San Francisco.  There are so
Completed

many interesting, talented people out here.  I'm looking forward to many new contacts.  We have a beautiful new home, with so many problems it would make good script for a Keystone Cop movie.  Guess the warm weather makes us giddy - we laugh over things that would  have us blowing our stacks in Illinois.  When will you be visiting out here again?  It will sure be nice to see you.
Happy New Year!
Affectionately,
Jean
Completed

letterhead  MRS. WILLIAM ARTHUR STOUT   435 NORTH HOUGH STREET  BARRINGTON, ILLINOIS
Dear Jack -

     Thanks so much for dropping me the card - I enjoyed the conversation over radio more than I imagined I would.  You sounded just the same - it was just like talking to you in  our office again.   Guess I'm either getting old or else, as dear old Cal said, "over emotional."  It was so good just to hear you - I remember your facial expressions so well that if the program had been telecast I couldn't have seen you more clearly - and
Completed

anyway the inner amusement that twinkles out of your eyes when you so tactfully turn a phrase of double entendre is better underlined:  remembered than hunted out through the cameras eye.  I had many a good chuckle last night!

   I enjoyed your Christmas note again as I sifted some overdue correspondence recently.  You haven't mentioned Arthur recently, I note.  Has he finally just faded away?
   Don't recall if we shared an appreciation of Shakespeare or
Completed

not, but Romeo and Juliet was a fine performance last night.  Television, there again, is quite inadequate, but I felt they did as well as they could, and considering that the program would be viewed by an audience perhaps only slightly composed of Shakespeare devotees, the form was quite true.

    Did I understand correctly that double underline:  They Seek a City is on the market?
    By the way, you will perhaps be amused to know that out here, where snobbery is the keystone
Completed

of social success, the group considered underlined:  the most intellectual, [[underlined: the most]  unbearably snobbish, etc., is one that "understands" Sandburg's stuff.  Apparently they get together with their lorgnettes, champagne and each others wives and read his works and fall into a Presley-fan-club swoon.  Two of my acquaintances avoid me since about a month ago when a discussion of poetry came up and I said Sandburg had long been one of my favorites!  This suburban life has its amusing angles.  The main problem connected with any
Completed

pseudo-cultural activity out here is that the social climbers either join a fashionable group without the foggiest notion of its original cultural purpose, or they learn a underlined:   little bit and then are considered experts an elected to the "board" of the group (this town is positively saturated with all kinds of "board members") or on the other hand, people who really do know something about music, art, literature, theater, etc., try getting together for genuinely worthwhile sharing of abilities and experiences
Completed

but soon find that social pressures have compelled them to attend a "board meeting" that same night, so they fall by the wayside.  It's too bad -- the town is full of lonely people with lots of friends.

    At the moment I'm the production manager for the play double underline:  Harvey, which is to be performed April 5 and 6 as a benefit for the Northwest Hospital, to be built in Arlington Heights.  That's a wonderful job -- I've met some worthwhile non board members who seem just as pleased to meet me.
Completed

I've gotten an amusing reputation out here - I do poster work for church and school functions occasionally, so I'm "underlined: so artistic;"  I can't stand to piddle over a job I'm asked to do and so do it promptly, so I'm "underlined: so efficient;"  I manage to keep my children clothed, fed and at least underlined: informed that they shouldn't flush other childrens lunches and mittens down the school toilets, so I'm triple underline under "r" "remarkable."   Isn't it fun?

   My son Randy, to whom you gave a copy of double underline:  Slappy Hooper,
Completed

seems to indicate, at least on preliminary tests, that he has a close to genius intelligence.  He also has a great musical gift - can play anything on any instrument almost immediately.  There are other things, too......  It sort of bewildered me at first, but now it looks like my little son John is similarly equipped, so the three of us just enjoy each other extra much via knowing looks, and go on merrily being a part of the Stout clan.  The Stouts have always been just a bit
Completed

unusual, so nobody pays too much notice to Randy.  His older twin brother and sister, for example, have just come around to underlined: expecting Randy to excel their scholastic prowess.

  Well -- no point in running the pen out of ink all at once.  Guess this should be the end.  Don't know just when, but I'll be downtown some year, so I'll come see you -

Best wishes,
Jean
Completed

letterhead  MRS. WILLIAM ARTHUR STOUT  435 NORTH HOUGH STREET   BARRINGTON, ILLINOIS
Dear Jack,

  Many thanks for your card  - it's always fine to hear from you.
  Esta and I have talked over the phone and covered basic details, but she is short of farm-outable material and I'm not too surprised that I haven't had further word from her.
  Meanwhile my aunt, who is a bright gal successful both in editorial and commercial
Completed

art work, has been virtually nagging me via airmail letters from San Francisco, to get busy on a collection of short stories for children, for which she will do illustrations.  I feel that a collection per se is a poor idea; short stories individually bound are better, but again a poor idea since the Golden books and Wonder books have quite a corner on the field; medium-short stories are a better idea, but these I don't know too much
Completed

about - I class "Slappy Hooper" in this group - but can a book that size be done practically?  Seems I recall your saying the price is a stumbling block.

    Can a beginner, such as this ignorant one, hope to be successful in submitting an illustrated story to Simon and Schuster for the Golden book series, or what might be another angle?
    I trust you're reasonably chipper - let me hear from you.

Jean
Completed

letterhead  MRS. WILLIAM ARTHUR STOUT  435 NORTH HOUGH STREET   BARRINGTON, ILLINOIS
Dear Jack -

  Enclosed is a handbill distributed around these parts recently - I meant to rush it to you post haste, for I knew you would be most anxious to attend the meeting and aid and abet the speaker's good work by passing out a few meaty tracts, but somehow the sheet got mixed in with some recipes for meals in which
Completed

ground glass can be readily concealed, and only today did I rediscover it.  Unfortunately I am unable to produce high quality ground glass with my new Dormeyer grinding attachment for use on all mixers model XO174B, so my plans have suffered a temporary set-back, as did my efforts to let you in on the Barrington variety of holy rolling.  Alas --

    Max's death must have
Completed

come as somewhat of a relief to you and others who had known him well.  It underlined:  was he, wasn't it, who often camped with you in times of sudden need?  As I recall it was, and, while the manner of his demise was somewhat unsavory, still it seems to me that a once-great such as he, who fell so far from grace in later years, was well rewarded in this case for the posthumous reports are usually most generous.  It
Completed

seems to me that he could not have wished death to come in any other form.  How many such faded flowers are fortunate enough to flash one last gaudy bloom before the public eye?

    Your friend, Miss Diamond, has never felt called upon to contact me, so I must scratch about for other outlets.  Discouraging as it is, I grow increasingly aware that as one lives the months away in a little
Completed

town, not only does one lose all contact with the producing writers, but becomes mentally static.  I begin to think and talk in cliches, and almost cease to care that this is the case.  The one new feature in my life which may be considered to be a preservative for artistically creative impulses which occasionally rest lightly on me is that we now have a piano.  You may recall that concert piano was my
Completed

goal prior to marriage #1, and that I have done some composing as well as performing.  After several years of virtual inactivity musically, there a [sic] dozens of cobwebs to be cleaned away, but the cleaning is a joy and inspiration.What expression I no longer put in writing I put in music now.  Seems like these years have bettered my interpretive sense, and by the same token perhaps devotion to music for a time while my children
Completed

grow will season my literary sense.  Fine music is seldom cluttered, and if I can attune my thought patterns to the purity and brilliance of music once again, perhaps I shall ultimately produce less cluttered writing -- which means that I must either strive for perfection or cease to try at all, for mediocricy [sic] in passion produces a tin-horn Christ.  I've set
Completed

myself a challenging course and find each small step of progress only increases the challenge.

    At this point I have reread the foregoing pages and come to the conclusion that I have said most of what I meant to say to you - and in a much too lengthy manner.  I'm hungry for conversation - please drop me a line soon.  I do hope you're well --

Hassled, but affectionately yours,
Jean
Completed

in pencil in top margin  [1950s]
letterhead  MRS. WILLIAM ARTHUR STOUT  435 NORTH HOUGH STREET   BARRINGTON, ILLINOIS
Dear Jack -

       Ours is not to question why - we must be content to cry.
       Your son's sudden passing must have, indeed, made your very soul weep.  I can't tell you how my heart goes out to you.  When a stranger's boy goes I'm pretty glib with the cliches about God's will and all that, but the smooth talk escapes me when the tragedy hits someone I'm
Completed

so fond of.  I can't even make a nasty remark about his wife - the worst of it is, of course, that my own conscience twinged when I read your letter, for my Moberly boy was one of the ones who had big ups and bad downs, and I left hm, and while we've never been able to discover the true facts, the reports were that he had been mortally injured while drunk after we had been separated about two months.  It's so hard sometimes for me to know whether
Completed

I should have stuck it out with him and finally helped him to have more ups than downs.  I'm appalled that Tom's wife was so cold about his death, however.  One thing I'd like to take the liberty of doing Jack - let me suggest that in case she should ever come to you and Gladys for help of any kind, don't let your grandson's little hands get so firm a hold on your heart that she may also gain entry.   I know from my own and many
Completed

others' experience, that once a girl leaves her man, she must make her way alone thereafter.  My folks didn't let me, and under their influence I got myself into a situation here almost as bad as I thought the first one was.  Were it not for the fact that I have these four lovely children I couldn't stand this.  Bill and I discover more each day what an imperfect match we are.  But the psychologists say that if you try hard to love a
Completed

person you ultimately will, and I'll try as long as I live, for I'll never leave another husband.  At any rate - to protect yourself and Tom's family - let them have died with him, at least for a few years.

    Jack, I've never quite understood people I guess.  Pat meant a lot to me, and when she failed to ever answer my letters after Bill and I were married, it hurt.  Tell me who she's married.  Is she going to continue working?  If
Completed

you can give me her address I'd like to send a greeting.  By now I can't even locate her old address.

    How is old frog face Fisk?  Still as ridiculous as ever I suppose.  What a sacrilege it is to give such a high title as his to someone as much a mockery of the station as he.  Phooey!
    I've run out of paper - so this is it.  Write soon again.

As ever,
Jean
Completed

letterhead  MRS. WILLIAM ARTHUR STOUT  435 NORTH HOUGH STREET   BARRINGTON, ILLINOIS
June 6, 1954
Dear Jack -

     After three arduous months I have finally succeeded in "digging out" far enough to avoid feeling shame as I take a few moments for correspondence.  I guess I'll never amount to much, for I have such an overdeveloped conscience about my fancied duties as wife and mother that my personal interests
Completed

II
seem to get pushed further and further into the background.  Not one of the few people with whom I correspond have been treated to a sample of my inimitable scrawl for lo these past months.  You are so very good about writing prompt answers - I guess in your case I sit me down and write to  you when my rope is growing perilously short and I need words from you almost at once.  Every letter you have
Completed

III
sent has left me craving the next, and ridiculous tho' it sounds I re-read your letters with certain frequency.

    What has come of underlined:  Little Big Shorty?  Spring is sweating into summer and unless you plan to retire to your Missouri river bank while shortening underlined:  Shorty you must have it in shape by now.
     Jack - I did sit down and write a most spirited inquiry concerning Win's show, and at least three of the other
Completed

IV
mothers here in Barrington got out their best stationery and also wrote, but we have not been honored by so much as a postcard in reply.  What [underlined:  has]] become of him?

    School will close tomorrow and my summer sentence will begin.  I can't say I relish the prospects of having my chickens under foot all day from here on.  Of course I'm about done in just now, for I have been wallpapering, digging gardens, & doing much too much dear old christian work for the
Completed

V
church (now that I am a Methodist in good standing, and have my chicks thoroughly uprooted from the local school of makeral [sic] snappers, I'm under constant fire from that school and subject to constant call from the Methodists who seem to think I look so well carrying a cross that they should add a few thorns to complete the effect.)  It's been a delightful spring.

   Come fall I'll be teaching piano afternoons and running a
Completed

VI
small and very snooty nursery school mornings.   Just now I'm being snooty about which snooty children belonging to which of the snootiest snoots will be accepted.  I've decided that the least this year of sudden motherhood should have done for me is to prepare me for mothering other people's kids part time for profit!  Not that I need children around, but I figure by the end of this summer I should be adequately immunized against their pretty wiles and
Completed

VII
able to run a pretty efficient organization at a considerable profit.

   I suppose this will either catch you just as you are leaving for your vacation, or just miss you, but at any rate please write as son as you can.  My tired old soul could stand the spiritual upliftment induced by a few good tracts, incidentally --

Affectionately
Jean
Completed
